This mode also features a Family Game sub-mode, that allows up to four family members to race and bet. The commands are quite simple, press I to use your whip, or press II to jump over obstacles. Power-ups can be collected to increase stamina, speed, but there are also power-downs.
title: World Jockey

description: KickBall is a single-screen (no-scrolling) action game for one or two players. It is a strange mix of two other sports games: baseball and dodgeball. Add to this strange teams: wrestlers, seals, moles, sumos, Schubibin Men, and so on.
title: KickBall

description:
Mahjong Gokū Special is the first mahjong game for the TurboGrafx using characters from Xi You Ji (aka "Journey to the West"), a classic Chinese novel. It was followed by Mahjong Gokū Tenjiku, four years later, by the same developer.

The player can choose to play one of the four characters from Xi You Ji: the famous Sun Wukong (a Monkey King called Sun Gokū in Japan, hence the title of the game), the pig Bajie, and two other "animals" (a dragon and a bird). It is a classic mahjong game with RPG elements, so Sun Gokū must make his way across a map, facing enemies at every stop. The only way to progress in the adventure is to defeat the enemies by winning at the mahjong table.
title: Mahjong Gokū Special

description: Tsuru Teruhito no Jissen Kabushiki Bai Bai Game is a stock-buying simulation game. The player has to keep an eye on stock market reports, and instruct his secretary to buy or sell.
title: Tsuru Teruhito no Jissen Kabushiki Bai Bai Game

description: Quiz Tōkōshashin is a trivia game in which the player answers questions to removes tiles covering nude anime-style girls.
title: Quiz Tōkōshashin

description:
Spin Pair is a Tetris kind of game, but with falling shapes which are half full, half empty. The player has to rotate these halves so that a full half matches an empty half below.

The game features four game modes : Normal, Story, Battle and VS, a special 2-player mode, for owners of PC Engine GT consoles, using a COM Link Cable.
title: Spin Pair

description: Shōgi - Shodan Icchokusen is an adaptation of Shogi for the TurboGrafx-16. For one or two players, the gameplay is identical to other Shogi games: the player controls various figures on a 2D 9x9 board. The goal is to reach shodan, the highest level.
title: Shōgi: Shodan Icchokusen

description:
Shōgi Shoshinsha Muyō is a shōgi simulation game. It was created by Home Data with supervision from the Japan Shōgi Association. The player can choose from AI difficulty levels 1 to 8. However, the effectiveness of the AI depends on the time limit set for it. For example, if you give it a short amount of time to think, it won't have time to think of as good of a move as if you gave it a very long or infinite time limit.

In addition, the game also has a Tsume Shōgi mode for players to enjoy. The player can select from 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, and 15-move Tsume Shōgi problems. The game also has a mode to watch eight historical shōgi matches. This way, the player can study the games and learn and strengthen their skills. If the player wishes to learn from their own mistakes, they can do so by using the replay mode at the end of a game. This mode allows the player to go to any move at any time of the game just played.

During the game, there are various settings that can be changed. These include flipping the board, changing the board and piece design, and whether or not to have audio or voice. Through an external device such as the PC Engine Memory Base 128, the player can save their progress to one of several game save slots and load them for later play.
title: Shōgi Shoshinsha Muyō

description: Kattobi! Takuhai Kun puts the player in the role of a delivery boy, driving around neighborhoods to deliver packages while avoiding various obstacles, like the police or package thieves.
title: Kattobi! Takuhai Kun

description: Based off the NHK program of the same name, Niko Niko Pun is a platformer aimed at very young children. As such, the design is very lenient, emphasizing long timers, enemies that move slowly and predictably, and little room in each level to get sidetracked. However, the player can occasionally engage in side goals like completing simple puzzles or talking to other characters.
title: NHK Okāsan to Issho: Niko Niko Pun

description: It is the year 2018 and aliens have made contact with the Earth. Adapted from Fujiko Fujio's manga, the game can have up to four players in one of three gameplay settings. The player's objective is to create a tourism industry suited for both humans and aliens alike. Taking on the style of Monopoly, the player travels across the board with a pair of die to purchase available property, gain income, and utilize services. Mini-games can be played throughout to earn some extra bonuses.
title: 21 Emon: Mezase! Hotel Ō

description: This limited edition of Bomberman features up to five players trying top each other in a three-minute battle, in which one player must win five matches to gain first place. When there are less than five players, two monster enemy-types take the place of the absent players. Graphics are simpler and come in one theme with randomized power-ups. The two modes, "Users Battle 1" and "User Battle 2," are near identical, with the latter providing skull power-ups, similar to the Normal and Skull modes from the original game.
title: Bomberman Users Battle

description: Based on the sci-fi anime series of the same name, the player controls one of the four Knight Sabers to investigate a mysterious group of maverick boomers on a robbery spree to steal specific electronic parts. The interface has nine actions to interact with environment of the current location, as well as an inventory menu with a use command. Dialogue options appear when conversing with a character. In later stages of the game, labyrinthine buildings have random turn-based combat encounters which allow one of the Knight Sabers in hard suits to perform a number of actions to destroy the opponent.
title: Bubblegum Crash!

description: Taking on a futuristic theme of dodgeball, the playing team Fire Bombers go up against six opposing teams in various courts to become the best of the best. The object is knock out every member of the opposing team with hard throws and avoid the playing team members getting hit in turn. In addition to the Tournament Mode, there is also battle versus modes for single and two players.
title: Cyber Dodge

description: Like many video game adaptations of mahjong, this one follows the traditional rules. This game however simplifies the tile game with a beginner mode providing tips, which recommend the best tiles to discard. There also exist cheat items which can be earned and used to have an unfair advantage over opponents. There are a total of twelve different opponents each of which the player faces in a two opponent match.
title: Wai Wai Mahjong: Yukai na Janyū-tachi

description: This fighting game takes place in a distant future where giant robots are used for fighting matches. There are four modes the game can be played including the one player, versus, edit and tournament modes. To progress through the tournament, the player has to beat all three rivals on each section of the stadium. Before each match the player can allocate points to change the PC's speed, power or armor. In later stages the player will have the opportunity to equip front and rear weapons. The player fights opponents in a race track styled arena, avoiding incoming obstacles while engaging the current opponent. Obstacles can be used against the opponent.
title: Fighting Run

description: This game serves as a remake of Tsuppari Ōzumō. Upon starting the game, the player sumo wrestler's name and facial appearance can be customized. Using button and movement combos, the player must beat the opponent, either by wrestling him to the ground or forcing him out of bounds. Matches take place in one of different stadiums. There are also outdoor bonus mini-games in between some matches.
title: Tsuppari Ōzumō: Heisei Ban

description:
The Mandler Army is prepping for a counter attack on humanity. The new military spacecraft Wing Galibur II is on the job to eliminate the threat.

Using mechanics from its prequels, this vertical-scrolling shoot-em-up game consists of shooting both flying and stationary enemies across stages in space and planetary surfaces with a boss at the end of each stage. The player's ship can be powered up to six levels (with a temporary phoenix invincibility attack after getting max power) and can store up to three formation attack charges for added protection and firepower.
title: Terra Cresta II: Mandler no Gyakushū

description:
The protagonist is dragged into the fantasy world of a manga book and becomes the Dragon Child Fighter. In order to escape, he must liberate five dragon statuettes that will grant him a wish after they are all united.

The gameplay is a straightforward platformer filled with enemies and hazards. In between traversing the dangerous areas, they player can find towns where NPCs can provide information and services. A sub-boss must be defeated before facing a proper boss in adult form.
title: Tatsunoko Fighter

description: By the 24th century, humans have picked up on a sport that involves robots battling each other in an arena. There are twelves robots to choose from. Each robot has 4 statistics and 15 character traits. The traits can be modified and allocated by the number of leftover points the player currently has. In the grid-based arena, the player can utilize the robot's powers for attack and defense moves with the goal of beating all eleven robots for the number one rank.
title: Super Metal Crusher

description: In the year 2930 and the planet's energy sources are running out. The player controls a capital ship to navigate the Solar System, locate an energy source and send out a unit to harness the energy. Planet positions change due to revolving around the sun. Navigating carries some risks, which if taken unwisely can destroy the capital ship and end the game. Piloting a unit takes the form of a third-person shooter with space objects and alien enemies. Shooting enemies acquires energy, while getting hit damages the shields.
title: Spiral Wave

description: The game is based around the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600. The player takes control of Tokugawa Ieyasu's finest general to march samurai and other units down roads across the map to defend friendly territories and fight any Toyotomi coalition invaders that come. Battles are done in hexagonal grids, commanding divisions of men to attack the appropriate enemy groups.
title: Sekigahara

description:
In 1999, the evil Belzebuth emerges from darkness and sends out his demon wrestlers against the human race, challenging them to a tournament that will spell their doom upon losing. Doctor Takeru Yamato bio-engineers his own mutant wrestlers to take the challenge and perhaps save humankind.

After choosing a mutant wrestler, the player begins with 30 power points adjust five attributes (including Hit Points, Strength, Magic Points, Stamina Points, and Guts) that will make the mutant stand a better chance in the wrestling ring. Combat takes the form of picking one several tactics (defense, magic, attack or special move) and a randomly generated number which indicates how effect the tactic will be. Likewise the demon will also have their own chosen tactic and random number. The player gets the upper hand if the random number is higher than the opponent's. The loser is the wrestler who loses all hit points.
title: Monster Pro Wrestling

description: In this game of golf, up to four players can compete in two different courses with eighteen holes each. Standard features include the direction and angle of hitting the ball, the type of club to use, and how much swing power to apply. The golf game is always represented from a bird's eye view, zooming in closer when the ball reaches the hole zone. The caddy can also offer advice.
title: Ganbare! Golf Boys

description: Based on the manga and anime of the same name, the titular hero Agedama goes into action to beat a monster clan led by an evil dragon. Each level works as an auto-runner (with the occasional platformer) that has the player attacking and dodging every monster that comes. Agedama can shoot projectiles, a roll maneuver or perform limited magic attacks. The kind of powers Agedama can use are dependent on the enemy pickups and the position of the indicator on the power gauge.
title: Genji Tsūshin Agedama

description: Danpei Ichigeki is a practiced elementary school dodgeball player for the Tamagawa Team, who are about to challenge seven other dodgeball teams in the upcoming tournament. The dodgeball mechanics consist of moving a selected player around the field and making a charged ball throw, followed by dynamic cutscenes that require the opposing player to move and interact during a ball launch, while the cutscene is playing. The game can be played in story mode, in which the player does an adventure driven game in control of Danpei or in versus mode, in which the player can be any one of the eight teams.
title: Honō no Tōkyūji: Dodge Danpei

description:
Taking the formula of the previous game, the player picks a team from a selection of ten fictional baseball teams, selects which member is the pitcher, then controls the pitcher during a strike session, and the fielders while the ball flies. There are five modes in the game:

  • Versus Mode has two players facing each other in one game.
  • Open Mode is similar to Versus, but playing against the computer instead of a human player.
  • Pennant Mode takes the player to the baseball tournament, facing and challenging opposing teams, one after another.
  • All Star Mode enables the player to pick players for a team based on performance in a single game.
  • Home Run Mode allows the player to have a go at batting and score a run.

The player is also free to edit the All Star team members in any order and change their names.
title: Power League II

description: The third installment of the Power League series continues the formula where the player controls the pitcher and the fielders. Power League III features a total of twelve different teams, three baseball stadiums, and additional metrics to keep score of all player positions. There are the traditional game modes including Open, Pennant, All Star, and Home Run, plus a Watch Mode where both players are computer controlled. The player is also free to edit teams and members.
title: Power League III

description: J.League Greatest Eleven takes place during the 1993 football season in Japan. The game can be played in J.League mode for 1 or 2 players against the computer, or the Exhibition mode, which is similar to J.League mode, but also allows up to four human players to compete. Players can choose from ten local Japanese teams. Before a match begins, one out a few suitable formations can be picked and the team players can be assigned to particular positions. Scoring the highest points for goals throughout the tournament earns the player top ranks and the J.League Cup.
title: J.League Greatest Eleven

description:
It is the 1989 season for Nippon Professional Baseball. The player chooses from six of the home teams against six opposing teams. There are three available modes of gameplay:

  • Open Mode consists of a friendly match against a CPU opponent.
  • Pennant consists of a series of matches within 130 days.
  • Versus Mode puts the player in a match against a human opponent.

Upon getting into the game, the player needs to manage the baseball players of the chosen team before taking control of the batter.
title: Kore ga Pro Yakyū '89

description: This game is a followup to Kore ga Pro Yakyū '89 with the same teams (both home and opposing), but with different players based on the 1990 season for Nippon Professional Baseball, featuring a new baseball stadium.
title: Kore ga Pro Yakyū '90

description: The game takes place at a Mahjong Strip Club, where the player challenges a number of gals as well as men to classic Mahjong matches. If the player manages to score better than the opponent, the gal will do a strip tease. In the case of male opponents, the player will simply punch up the man upon winning.
title: Mahjong Gakuen: Tōma Sōhirō Tōjō

description: This version of Mahjong Gakuen: Tōma Sōhirō Tōjō is almost identical but includes censorship for the gals in their strip tease, covering the nudity with swimwear.
title: Mahjong Gakuen Mild: Tōma Sōshirō Tōjō

description: An entire empire has been overrun by evil forces. Three heroes step forward to fight said forces and save the land. The player picks one of the heroes and travels to various locations across the map, challenging opponents to Mahjong matches. Each match won by the player liberates an area. Additional heroes are unlockable later in the game.
title: Mahjong Haōden: Kaiser's Quest

description: Taking place in a four fictional stadiums with fourteen fictional teams (depicted by initial letters), Naxat Stadium goes by the traditional rules of Japanese professional baseball, in four different modes including a single one or two player match, a watch mode with two computer opponents, and the pennant mode for a series of matches against all opposing teams, plus options to edit the players and the teams.
title: Naxat Stadium

description: The concept of the game is basically beating CPU opponents in a game of Mahjong. There are two different modes. The first mode is the Normal mode with single Mahjong match against anime girls. The other is a story mode called Mahjong Wars, in which the protagonist travels across a city map to challenge various opponents to matches, gaining experience and solving puzzles.
title: Mahjong Shikaku Retsuden: Mahjong Wars

description: The games follows the story of the Japanese folktale hero Momotarō (a.k.a. Peach Boy) travelling across a series of platform levels to rid the land of the evil demons. In each level Momotarō can beat monsters with his sword, dodge deadly traps, and earn some currency. NPCs can give some information, start up a game of Janken or sell some upgrades. A few of those levels take place underwater.
title: Momotarō Katsugeki

description:
Based on an agricultural TV show, Moo Cow Island is facing serious issues after a witch called Jaren creates a series of volcanoes, and a black path, which in turn unleashes monsters on to the land.

The player takes control of the titular cow farmer Daichi-kun. The aim of the game is to build up a successful arable farm by planting and harvesting crops, then selling them for money to buy farming supplies, while clearing monsters and the ash they deposit to protect the crops. Success of the farm is dependent on keeping the Geiger No Machine running.
title: Daichi-kun Crisis: Do Natural

description:
The game is an adaptation of NHK's historical drama TV series "Taiga Drama" set in 14th century Japan during the Nanboku-chō period in a war between the Ashikaga shogunate and the Southern Court.

After picking a side in the war, the player controls regiments of foot soldiers, archers and cavalry in hexagonal grid-based areas to conquer all opposition and put a firm foothold across the lands. In typical rock-paper-scissors fashion, certain unit types are better at slaying others (e.g. spearmen easily take down cavalry).
title: NHK Taiga Drama: Taiheiki

description: While maintaining similarities to its prequel, the fifth game of the series has some cosmetic improvements to the graphics and sprite animations, as well as gameplay upgrades like improved automatic movement for fielders and balanced difficulty. There are new fictional baseball teams, which use the names of real baseball players.
title: Power League 5

description: Staying mainly the same as the previous two games, this seventh installment of the Power League series now includes real-life Nippon Professional Baseball teams from the 1993 baseball season, and minor improvements to the game mechanics.
title: Power League '93

description: This game shares much in common with its predecessor Pro Yakyū World Stadium, but now offers a total of 14 different teams, plus two unlockable secret teams. Throughout the tournament, the player can choose which team they want to challenge next. There are small changes to the gameplay such as fielders making additional moves.
title: Pro Yakyū World Stadium '91

description: The Detana Society have kidnapped the manager of the pachinko center in attempt to takeover the business. Pachio-kun steps forth to thwart this nefarious plan. The game starts Pachio in a pachinko parlor, where the goal is to beat every pachinko machine and win additional balls. Every machine has a different layout. Once all machines are beaten, Pachio is free to move on to the next parlor.
title: Pachio-kun: Jūban Shōbu

description: Strife Sisters is a homebrew strategy RPG in which players take control of two girls: Rei and Violet that can recruit various types of troops to assist them in battles between each stage. In the stages, players and enemies take a turn to move and attack. These attacks are animated in a separate field.
title: Strife Sisters
